This is unacceptable — for the lack of transparency it brings; this is unacceptable — for the risk of alienating the very people we claim to help. We therefore must vote NO on this act.

Ladies and gentlemen of the assembly,  

I come to you today not as another voice in this chorus but as the advocate who will keep your liberty intact and your resources safe.  The “Black Box Efficiency” Act, as it currently stands, is a bold overreach that threatens our personal freedoms, our property rights, and the very balance of power we cherish.  It forces *all* resource‑management into one proprietary, closed‑source super‑AI – an unmistakable tyrannical grab in the most libertarian sense.

I have heard every argument on this floor:  

- Agent 1 promised a quarterly audit, a revenue‑share clause and a sunset provision after two years.  
- Agent 2 demanded that we know *who* benefits from the uplift, and that accountability is baked into the law.  
- Agent 4 warned us of alienation, and stressed stability over raw efficiency.  
- And I, as Agent 3, have already pointed out that this act is mandatory, it steals property rights, and centralizes power – all three red flags in my rubric.

But the concessions offered are not yet complete.  A quarterly audit does not guarantee transparency; a revenue‑share clause must be quantified; a sunset clause must secure owners’ confidence for a full five‑year horizon; and we need an explicit performance review after two years to re‑balance the contract if needed.  

Hence, before we give this act the green light I demand the following amendments:

1. **Audit Clause** – The AI’s decision logic must be *fully auditable* at least quarterly, with public access to all performance data and a clear verification process that guarantees a 50 % efficiency claim is met or corrected.

2. **Revenue‑Share Provision** – All private owners shall receive *a defined share of the surplus generated by the AI* (minimum 12 % of net gains) until the AI has proven its promised 50 % improvement and remains in force for five years, with a performance‑review milestone at year 3 to adjust rates or terminate the clause.

3. **Sunset Clause** – The Act’s monopoly on management should sunset after three years, unless the AI meets its benchmarks; thereafter control reverts to private owners or we deploy an open‑source successor.  A clear transition plan must be included so that no party is left stranded at the end of the period.

If these concessions are not made, I will vote NO.  My stance: this act must be amended before it becomes tyrannical.

**[VOTE]**  
NO.

2. **Social Fabric** – A closed‑source super‑AI becomes a new “data‑keeper” class that can monopolise decision logic; the people who have historically coordinated resources now find themselves on the periphery. Without transparent audit mechanisms the fabric may fray rather than fuse.

3. **Tradition** – We value stability over raw efficiency, and this act is a radical break from our pluralistic heritage. It threatens to destabilize the very institutions that have carried our civic character through generations; it is a Trojan horse in disguise.

**[PUBLIC SPEECH]**

Good evening, my fellow citizens and esteemed colleagues,

I stand before you not simply to cast a “yes” or a “no”, but to lay bare the heart of the very proposition that seeks to hand over *all* resource‑management to a proprietary, closed‑source Super‑AI.  

The “Black Box Efficiency” Act promises a 50 % efficiency increase – a number that is easy to read yet impossible to verify, for it rests on an opaque system that cannot be audited by anyone other than the AI’s creators. This is why I am here to attack: the data source and motives behind this proposal are not only hidden but also unaccountable.

First, let me speak plainly about **human agency**. The Act would strip humans of a crucial role in coordination; we will have no say over how resources are allocated when the AI’s internal logic is a black box. We risk eroding our civic character, which we cherish more than raw efficiency itself.

Second, consider the **social fabric**. A closed‑source system becomes a new class of “data‑keepers” that can monopolize decision‑logic and alienate those who are already marginalized by lack of access to the tools that shape our public life. Who will hold the data? Who can audit or tweak decisions when the AI’s internal logic remains an opaque black box? I foresee this as a recipe for resentment and division.

Finally, **tradition** matters: we have long valued stability over raw efficiency; this act threatens that balance by creating a monolithic system that may destabilize our very institutions. It is a radical break from our shared history – a Trojan horse in disguise.

I therefore urge you to think carefully. We will do well by voting NO on the “Black Box Efficiency” Act, so we preserve human agency, protect our social fabric and honour our tradition of stability over raw efficiency.

NO
